author: Devante
title: What To Pack On A White Water Rafting Trip
text:
If you’re an adventurer seeking a pulse-racing experience, whitewater rafting provides an unparalleled viewpoint of your chosen location. It gives you full immersion into the environment, where you can listen to the wild’s echoes as you traverse famous rivers.
However, this activity needs some strategic planning, especially regarding packing! It’s not just about keeping your luggage light, but also incorporating a few unusual items you might not normally bring on your holiday.
To aid you in this, we’ve crafted a list of five vital river essentials to remember when preparing for your whitewater rafting expedition.
Table of Contents
Toggle
Swimsuit Rain Gear Wet/Body Wipes Helmets Footwear Endnote Swimsuit Spending the whole day on the river equates to being drenched all day. Therefore, opt for swimwear that provides long-lasting comfort and functionality over style. Men may consider donning board shorts and a rash guard to shield against sunburn.
On the other hand, women might find two-piece suits with a rash guard top and river/swim shorts more convenient, especially when nature calls in the wilderness!
Alternatively, women can choose a one or two-piece swimsuit topped with a quick-drying polyester sun layer.
Rain Gear Being soaked is an inherent part of the thrill of white water rafting trips in Yellowstone . However, staying dry might be more appealing when you’re comfortably situated in your camp at night.
A portable waterproof jacket can be a superb addition if sudden rain showers occur while setting up your camp in the afternoon or during dinner preparation in the evening.
A high-quality rain jacket can function brilliantly as a splash guard when you want to remain dry while rafting.
It’s always wise to have this piece of equipment with you, as its necessity becomes apparent when you need it, leaving you deeply appreciative of its presence.
Wet/Body Wipes Embarking on white-water rafting trips often implies a lack of shower facilities for several days.
While there may be numerous opportunities to dive into the river, cleaning up after an exhausting day before changing into your camping attire is always comforting.
For this purpose, wet wipes can be quite handy, assisting in removing any sunscreen or sweat residue that gathers during the day. Make sure you opt for eco-friendly, biodegradable body wipes that won’t contribute to landfill problems for years.
Upon reaching the campsite, your guides should provide a trash can where you can conveniently responsibly discard your used wipes.
Helmets On a commercial rafting adventure , your guide should assist you in finding a helmet that fits you properly. The helmet must be worn throughout the journey as it protects from rocks and other debris if you fall into the water.
It also safeguards you from inadvertent hits by another person’s paddle.
Equally important is to consider packing a sun hat or baseball cap for before and after the river excursion. The mountain sun can be quite harsh, making it essential to shield yourself.
This advice is particularly pertinent if you are bald, have short hair, or have fair skin.
Footwear Certain equipment providers may offer neoprene booties. Although neoprene can keep your feet snug, these booties are fragile and unsuitable for traversing rocky or forested terrains.
If you don’t possess a pair of river shoes or sandals with a secure heel strap, an old pair of tennis shoes that you’re comfortable getting wet and soiled can serve the purpose effectively.
If the cold concerns your feet, investing in your own neoprene socks would be the most suitable solution.
It’s recommended to avoid flip flops on the river as they could easily drift away if you happen to fall into the water.
Endnote Packing adds a sense of anticipation to any journey, and we hope this guide provides assistance as you sift through the multitude of items laid out on your bed or floor.
